posts.cooked: When in Teleop, the robot occasionally (every minute or so), has connection problems with our robot for a few seconds. The robot never disables, but 7 or so errors in quick succession show up reading: “﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿Warning ﻿﻿ 44004 ﻿﻿ FRC : The Driver Station has lost communication with the robot. ﻿﻿”   After a few seconds later the robot goes back to normal. This can even happen when its disabled, and doesn’t have any sorts of high voltage draw or anything. We are just using a standard radio and we got a new computer recently so that shouldn’t be a problem. What do you think the problem is?

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: My guess would be something is running in the background of the driver station computer that is blocking network traffic. Close any programs other than the DS, and check in Task Manager what else is running in the background. Also make sure any firewalls on the computer are disabled when connected to the robot.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
Run a Windows debloat tool if you can to remove a lot of the telemetry.

Make sure all the security and firewalls are off of the DS laptop.  You should have all green dots on the driver station status tab.

posts.name: Emile Hamwey
posts.cooked: Are you using an Ethernet switch? If so, what model?
There have always been all green dots on the DS, except when this issue is happening where they flash green and red. Also, I have disabled the firewalls and the issue persists.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
If this is happening when operating with laptop WiFi, but not with a wired connection:

Driver Station Laptop experiences rapid disconnects Technical

link_counts.title: Driver Station Laptop experiences rapid disconnects

posts.cooked: We are using the brainbox. We didn’t configure anything for it, because we didn’t think we had to. I believe most teams are using this, so have you heard any similar problems with it?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Brainbox Ethernet Switch Question / Match Issues Electrical

link_counts.title: Brainbox Ethernet Switch Question / Match Issues

posts.cooked:
Thanks, because this is certainly the issue. Our exact problem can be replicated by just opening the wifi menu of the computer, so it has to be the computer passively scanning for networks sometimes. I tried disabling background scanning as the tutorial recommends, but that ended up completely removing any ability to join wifi networks, so I undid it. I also tried disabling the 2.4 wifi connection for the computers wifi chip as was recommended somewhere else, but that made the robot wifi not work (its probably 2.4 only). I also tried decreasing the wifi roaming aggressiveness, but that didn’t change anything. The computer wifi chip is: “Realtek 8852BE Wireless LAN WiFi 6 PCI-E NIC” (as it shows up under device manager). Is there any ideas you have to disabling passive wifi scanning? I’ve heard that I could change the wifi driver but its already updated to the latest driver and I don’t know where to go for alternates. Any help would be appreciated!

Edit: The computer is running windows 11

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
This seems to be increasingly pervasive and ever-more-difficult to disable.  I’m only going to be able to do the same thing you can (searching Google for potentially relevant instructions).  Unfortunately, in these cases it seems like the best bet is simply not to use built-in WiFi on these machines, but instead use Ethernet with an external router/bridge.

You really should be using 5 GHz WiFi… 2.4 GHz is much too crowded.  Make sure you’ve programmed the robot radio for 5 GHz operation.

Thanks, we just updated the radio to use 5 GHz wifi and everything is now up to date. The same issue persists, however.

We should just be able to disable the passive computer wifi scanning, right?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: I would like to think it is possible to disable the passive scanning, but I don’t know the magic incantation to do so.  Microsoft seems to have buried it deeper and deeper in each Windows version.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
Peter_Johnson:

Unfortunately, in these cases it seems like the best bet is simply not to use built-in WiFi on these machines, but instead use Ethernet with an external router/bridge.

Somewhat fortunately, next year the solution to that might just be a second robot radio on the DS side, since that’s essentially what the field setup will be. Powering it will still be annoying (…maybe? It works down to about 5V…), but at least it’ll quickly become something teams have an extra of lying around. Hopefully we get a configuration tool to facilitate this exact setup.
